message_1:
Assuming standard conditions, calculate the standard enthalpy of combustion of methane (CH4), given that the standard enthalpies of formation of CH4 and H2O are -74.8 kJ/mol and -285.8 kJ/mol, respectively. The balanced chemical equation for the combustion of CH4 is:

CH4(g) + 2O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2H2O(l) 

What is the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for this reaction?
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the combustion of methane, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

The standard enthalpy of formation (ΔHf°) of O2 is 0 kJ/mol since it is in its elemental form. The standard enthalpy of formation of CO2 is -393.5 kJ/mol.

Now, we can plug in the values into the equation:

ΔH° = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.8 kJ/mol) + 2 × 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH° = (-393.5 - 571.6) - (-74.8)

ΔH° = -965.1 + 74.8

ΔH° = -890.3 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the combustion of methane is -890.3 kJ/mol.
